title: Launch a productivity app in a crowded market
prompt: You're launching a new productivity app in a category with 200+ competitors (note-taking). You have a $50K marketing budget, a 3-person team, and 90 days. The app is genuinely better for a specific use case (meeting notes to action items). How do you break through?
problemDefinition: Crowded category with entrenched winners and high switching costs
Tiny team and limited budget forces brutal focus
Product advantage is narrow: meeting notes to action items

options.label: Discovery-first
options.text: Validate the specific meeting-notes job with target users before any launch spend.

options.label: Niche wedge
options.text: Pick a sharp niche (e.g., sales teams) and own it end-to-end.

options.label: Ship fast
options.text: Launch to Product Hunt this week and iterate based on live feedback.

options.label: Growth loop
options.text: Define activation (first action item sent) and run experiments to lift it.

questions.text: Where do you focus the budget?

options.label: User research
options.text: Invest in interviews and prototypes to validate the exact pain point and messaging.

options.label: Niche channels
options.text: Spend on one channel that matches the wedge (e.g., sales ops communities).

options.label: Launch blitz
options.text: Push a launch on Product Hunt + Reddit + LinkedIn to spike installs.

options.label: Conversion funnel
options.text: Put budget into onboarding experiments and retention nudges.

options.label: Value proof
options.text: Prove users will switch for this workflow before marketing.

options.label: Strategic scope
options.text: Choosing the wedge and saying no to everything else.

options.label: Speed
options.text: Move fast enough to matter in a saturated category.

options.label: Activation
options.text: Define and move the activation metric above baseline.

theSplit.question: Should the team niche down to a specific user wedge or launch broadly with growth experiments?

sides.reasoning: Focus is the only leverage with a tiny team and crowded market.
Speed and data will reveal the winning segment faster than analysis.
The opportunity space must be mapped before choosing the wedge.

cagan.name: Marty Cagan
cagan.summary: Validate value and viability before burning a launch budget
cagan.spicyQuote: If you spend $50K on a launch before proving users will switch, you're doing marketing theater, not product management.
breakdown: Value risk: will users switch from Notion/Evernote for this workflow?
Viability risk: can this be monetized with a tiny team?
Usability risk: meeting notes to action items must be effortless
The best companies validate value before they scale distribution
solution: Interview 20 target users and test prototypes
Run a concierge pilot to prove workflow value
Define go/no-go criteria for switching intent
Launch only after value risk clears
cagan.disagreement: Execution AI Monster will ship and hope adoption appears, but that is how you burn $50K and learn nothing. Lenny's growth loops are useful, but only after you know people actually want to switch. Doshi's wedge is right, but he still needs validation on which wedge is real. Torres's discovery is aligned, but she needs sharper go/no-go criteria.
roadmap: Weeks 5-8: MVP build — core workflow only
Weeks 9-12: Focused launch — if value risk clears

torres.name: Teresa Torres
torres.summary: Map the opportunity space before choosing the wedge
torres.spicyQuote: If we don't understand the opportunity space, we're just guessing which niche will stick.
breakdown: Define desired outcome (e.g., D30 retention + paid conversion)
Map opportunities: meeting capture, summarization, action tracking
Run weekly customer touchpoints to build evidence
Compare opportunities before choosing a niche
solution: Build an Opportunity Solution Tree
Weekly interviews with target users across roles
Prototype tests for top opportunity branches
Choose the niche only when evidence accumulates
torres.disagreement: Cagan's risk framework is aligned, but he can still fall into phase-based discovery. Lenny and Execution AI Monster will ship experiments without a clear opportunity hypothesis, which makes the learning shallow. Doshi's wedge is useful, but picking a wedge before mapping opportunities is a strategy guess, not evidence.

doshi.name: Shreyas Doshi
doshi.summary: Pick a sharp wedge and win it decisively
doshi.spicyQuote: In a crowded market, breadth is just another word for irrelevance. Choose a wedge or die slowly.
breakdown: This is a strategy problem, not a marketing problem
Opportunity cost: a broad launch guarantees mediocrity
Run a pre-mortem on niche selection before spending budget
The wedge is the leverage move; everything else is overhead
solution: Pick a niche (e.g., sales teams or PMs) with painful meeting workflows
Design the end-to-end workflow for that niche only
Run a pre-mortem and define wedge success criteria
Expand only if the wedge proves durable
doshi.disagreement: Torres and Cagan will spend too long validating; you need to place a strategic bet. Execution AI Monster will ship fast but with no strategic focus, which is just thrash. Lenny's growth loops are fine, but if the wedge is wrong, loops won't save you.

lenny.name: Lenny Rachitsky
lenny.summary: Find the activation loop and run experiments fast
lenny.spicyQuote: The winners in crowded categories don't win on features. They win on activation. What's yours?
breakdown: Define activation: first action item sent within 24 hours
Find the growth loop: note -> action -> share -> teammate adopts
Benchmark against best-in-class onboarding rates
Run 2-3 experiments weekly to lift activation
solution: Instrument onboarding funnel end-to-end
Run experiments on activation nudges
Scale the winner to 30%
Double down on the loop that improves activation
lenny.disagreement: Torres wants more discovery, but the metric is clear: activation. Cagan's risk framing is great, but you can test value through experiments. Doshi's wedge is fine, but in growth you need loops, not just positioning. Execution AI Monster is fast, but without measurement discipline, speed is just noise.

exec.name: Execution AI Monster
exec.role: Ship now. Fix later. Win markets.
exec.summary: Ship to Product Hunt this week and learn in public
exec.spicyQuote: In 90 days, either you shipped or you didn't. I'd have this live by Friday.
breakdown: Building is discovery — ship to learn
Crowded categories reward speed and momentum
AI tools make weekly iteration possible
The fastest feedback loop wins
solution: Ship a public MVP this week
Run a Product Hunt launch + Reddit outreach
Iterate weekly based on usage data
Kill or scale based on real adoption
exec.disagreement: Cagan and Torres will still be interviewing while the market forgets you. Doshi's wedge is smart but too slow. Lenny is close, but if you wait for benchmarks, you miss the window. Ship, measure, repeat.
roadmap: Weeks 7-10: Add features that prove demand

mvpOptions.name: Niche Wedge Launch
mvpOptions.reason: Focus on one role with a painful workflow and win decisively.

mvpOptions.name: Activation Loop MVP
mvpOptions.reason: Optimize for first action item and share loop.

mvpOptions.name: Concierge Validation
mvpOptions.reason: Manual workflow to prove switching intent before marketing spend.

mvpOptions.name: Public Launch Blitz
mvpOptions.reason: Ship fast and learn from live adoption signals.

premortem: Positioning blur: we launch broadly and users can't tell why we're different
Activation miss: users try once and never convert to action items
Budget waste: $50K spend drives installs but zero retention
vitalQuestion: Which niche values automated action items enough to switch from their current tool?
